poem:
### The Lecture Hall

In crowded halls where whispers drift,  
young hearts in a curious shift.  
A glance meets thought, bold yet restrained,  
the line between learned and unchained.  

Books spread wide, quivers unfold,  
in twilight zones, stories retold.  
Gray between black and white,  
where love learns to recite.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "At 21, Madison Griffiths dated her university tutor. It was legal, consensual – and a messy grey area At the tail end of 2023, author Madison Griffiths posed a question on her Instagram: “Has anyone here ever been in a relationship with a professor or a tutor?” Hundreds of responses flooded in. There were those who revealed that their parents had met, many decades prior, in the lecture hall. Younger women reported they’d recently been". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
